## TanStack Query v5 Key Features & Best Practices

### Requirements & Core Changes

React Query v5 requires React 18.0 or later because it uses the new `useSyncExternalStore` hook, which is only available in React 18.0 and later.

### Status Naming Changes

The `loading` status has been renamed to `pending`, and the derived `isLoading` flag has been renamed to `isPending`. For mutations as well, the status has been changed from `loading` to `pending`. A new derived `isLoading` flag has been added that is implemented as `isPending && isFetching`.(no content)This means `isLoading` and `isInitialLoading` have the same thing, but `isInitialLoading` is deprecated and will be removed in the next major version.

### Suspense Support (Now Stable)

Suspense for data fetching is no longer experimental but fully supported. React Query ships with new `useSuspenseQuery`, `useSuspenseInfiniteQuery`, and `useSuspenseQueries` hooks.(no content)V5 also comes with an experimental integration for suspense on the server in Next.js. The react-query-next-experimental adapter allows you to write a single `useSuspenseQuery` which will initiate data fetching as early as possible on the server during SSR, then stream the result to the client.

### API Simplifications

The biggest breaking change in v5 is the removal of overloads. The API is now much more consistent - you always just pass one object.(no content)V5 renamed `cacheTime` to `gcTime` to better reflect what it's doing, merged `keepPreviousData` with `placeholderData`, renamed loading states to pending, and removed the callbacks from `useQuery`.

### Server-Side Retry Defaults

On the server, retry now defaults to 0 instead of 3. For prefetching, the default was always 0 retries, but since queries with suspense enabled can now execute directly on the server as well, they need to ensure no retries happen on the server.

### Infinite Queries Enhancement

V5 includes a new `maxPages` option for infinite queries to limit the number of pages to store in the query data and to refetch.

### Migration Tools

To make migration easier, v5 comes with a codemod. The codemod is a best-efforts attempt to help you migrate the breaking changes. Please review the generated code thoroughly!

### General Best Practices

TanStack is a powerful collection of headless utilities for building modern web applications. It includes all the essential features for modern state management: smart caching, background refetching, optimistic updates, and smooth error handling.(no content)While queries handle data fetching, mutations manage data changes like creating, updating, or deleting records. TanStack Query's mutation system gives you powerful features including optimistic updates, automatic retry logic, and smooth error handling.(no content)If you're building a React app in 2025, TanStack should be in your stack. ### Bundle Size

For a "Hello World" app, the approximate bundle sizes are:
- **React**: ~40kb (before adding UI libraries)
- **Vue**: ~20kb

React's bundle size, when compressed, is around 42.2 kB, significantly larger than Svelte's 1.6 kB.

### Performance Characteristics

**Svelte:**
Svelte takes a radically different approach by shifting much of the work to compile time. Instead of relying on a virtual DOM, Svelte compiles components into highly efficient JavaScript at build time, resulting in minimal runtime overhead. This means faster updates to the DOM and smaller bundle sizes.(no content)Svelte has no Virtual DOM, smallest bundles, and fastest performance. ## shadcn/ui vs Material UI vs Chakra UI Comparison (2025)

### Overview

Material-UI (now MUI) has dominated the enterprise space with its comprehensive design system. Chakra UI emerged as the developer-friendly alternative with its simple API and excellent TypeScript support. Now, shadcn/ui has disrupted the entire category with a radically different approach: copy-paste components instead of npm packages.

### Key Differences

**shadcn/ui**
- Not a component library in the traditional sense. You don't install it as a dependency from npm. Instead, it's a curated collection of beautifully designed, reusable components that you copy and paste directly into your project via a CLI command. These components are built using Radix UI for accessibility and behavior, and styled with Tailwind CSS.
- Once a component is in your codebase, it's yours. You have 100% control over its code, styling, and behavior.
- Excellent accessibility through Radix UI primitives with WAI-ARIA standards at their core. Zero runtime overhead because it's just Tailwind CSS with no runtime CSS-in-JS library.
- Compatible with React 19 and Tailwind v4.

**Material UI (MUI)**
- A cornerstone of the React ecosystem for years, providing a comprehensive suite of components that let developers build functional user interfaces with remarkable speed. Its adherence to Google's Material Design principles offers a consistent, predictable, and robust foundation.
- The downside is that it can sometimes feel restrictive. The components are designed to follow Material Design principles closely, which can limit creativity if you want to deviate from that design language.
- Provides robust RTL support and built-in locale providers for dozens of languages.

**Chakra UI**
- Designed for fast, accessible, and consistent React development. Its components are well-structured, responsive, and easy to theme. Requires Node 20+, and works great with Next.js.
- Emphasizes simplicity and accessibility, providing a set of modular, composable components that are easy to use and customize.
- Has built-in roles and focus styles for every component.

### When to Choose Each

**shadcn/ui**: For maximum control and a bespoke design system you own. **Chakra UI**: For the best-in-class developer experience and rapid, accessible development.(no content)**MUI**: For building internal tools or admin dashboards where speed of initial development trumps design uniqueness, or when your team is already proficient with it.(no content)Choose Material-UI for enterprise projects where comprehensive component libraries, advanced features, and team scalability outweigh bundle size concerns.

### Performance Considerations

If every KB matters, shadcn/ui wins. If developer speed trumps bundle size, Chakra UI excels.(no content)Lightweight Tailwind-based styling (used by shadcn/ui) outperforms Emotion/Styled Components used by MUI and Chakra.

### Trade-offs

For shadcn/ui: You are responsible for updates; if a bug is fixed upstream, you may need to re-copy the component. If you or your team are not fans of utility-first CSS, this is a non-starter.(no content)shadcn/ui requires familiarity with Tailwind CSS and React, and has a smaller community. MUI's extensive documentation and forums offer quicker troubleshooting.

### 2025 Recommendation

For most React projects in 2025, starting with Chakra UI is recommended for its excellent balance of developer experience, performance, and flexibility. It provides the fastest path to a polished UI while maintaining reasonable bundle sizes. Upgrade to shadcn/ui when performance becomes critical or when you need extensive customization.

## Overview

React Spectrum is a project that implements Adobe's Spectrum design language into React UI components.(no content)Spectrum offers open-source implementations such as Spectrum CSS, React Spectrum, and Spectrum Web Components, along with detailed usage guidelines.

## Key Libraries

### React Spectrum
React Spectrum is an implementation of Adobe's design system. If you're integrating with Adobe software or would like a complete component library to use in your project, look no further!(no content)React Spectrum components are designed with accessibility top-of-mind and include full screen reader and keyboard navigation support. React Spectrum components are designed to work with mouse, touch, and keyboard interactions.

### React Aria
React Aria is a collection of unstyled React components and hooks that helps you build accessible, high quality UI components for your own application or design system. If you're building a component library for the web from scratch with your own styling, start here.

### Spectrum CSS
Spectrum CSS is the standard CSS implementation of the Spectrum design language.(no content)Spectrum CSS should only be used by implementations of Spectrum, or very simple applications that only need things like typography, checkboxes, text fields, etc. Adobe maintains separate libraries written with web components and React that work in partnership with Spectrum CSS to create fully interactive Spectrum components.(no content)All components in this library have a peer dependency on @spectrum-css/tokens, which is a local package that serves up the Spectrum design tokens as CSS custom properties. These custom properties are leveraged in all components to create a cohesive visual language and to allow for easy theming.

## 2025 Updates

### January 2025 Release
The first release of 2025 includes a new firstDayOfWeek prop for calendar and date picker components, support for CSS transitions in overlay components, a new Autocomplete component in alpha, and a new React Aria test utils package.(no content)The new Autocomplete component is now available in alpha! Similar to a ComboBox, this component provides the ability to display a list of suggestions as the user types in a text input. However, it is more flexible, supporting use cases such as command palettes and searchable menus.

### October 2025 Release
This release brings some long-awaited features, including multi-selection in React Aria Select and enhanced animation support across components. For example, Disclosure now provides CSS variables to easily animate expanding and collapsing.

## Visual Languages (Spectrum CSS)
.spectrum is the default visual language representing the Spectrum 2 foundations. .spectrum--legacy is the legacy Spectrum 1 visual language, which will be deprecated in Spectrum 2.

## Recommendations for React Development
Adobe recommends using swc-react over React Spectrum in add-ons based on React, because it currently offers a more comprehensive set of components which provide built-in benefits, and is more actively supported.(no content)Spectrum Web Components are native web components that work with vanilla JavaScript, while swc-react provides React wrapper components for the same Spectrum Web Components. Use Spectrum Web Components for basic JavaScript projects and swc-react for React-based add-ons.
